ranked_diseases.explanation: Perfect match with peripheral nerve amyloidosis and gastrointestinal symptoms (alternating diarrhea/constipation). Age of presentation (62 years) fits late-onset variant. Most common form of hereditary systemic amyloidosis.
Can cause peripheral neuropathy and GI symptoms, though less commonly affects peripheral nerves compared to transthyretin amyloidosis. Typically presents in middle to late adulthood.
Systemic amyloidosis that can involve peripheral nerves and cause GI symptoms, but peripheral neuropathy is less prominent than in TTR amyloidosis. Age fits the typical presentation.
Finnish type amyloidosis that can cause peripheral neuropathy, though GI symptoms are less common. Typically presents with corneal lattice dystrophy first, which is not mentioned here.
Rare hereditary amyloidosis that can affect multiple organs including nerves and GI tract. Peripheral neuropathy is not the most prominent feature but can occur.
Though not strictly hereditary, AL amyloidosis commonly presents in this age group with peripheral neuropathy and GI symptoms. Most common form of systemic amyloidosis overall.
